17.72.text: Good morning. My name is Manasvini Mohan.

20.58.text:
I am 17 years old and currently still in school
studying for my A Levels.

25.60.text:
I first heard of the Women's Equality Party while
watching a talk given at LSE by the former Prime Minister

32.00.text:
of Australia, Julia Gillard. It just so happens
that at that time, I was researching women's

38.55.text:
underrepresentation in Parliament for a project
I was doing in school and so the notion of

43.75.text: a Women's Equality Party intrigued me straight away.

46.71.text:
As soon as I went home that evening, I Googled
the Women's Equality Party or "WE" as they are known,

53.38.text:
read up on the work they do and
emailed them with some questions.

57.00.text:
Very shortly after that, I spent a few days
volunteering at the party's London headquarters.

63.77.text:
During this time, it became clear to me that
first and foremost, WE aim to remove the obstacles

71.15.text:
and barriers facing women in Britain today.
I decided to become a member not only because

77.18.text:
I am a woman and a feminist, but because I
believe the party's work will benefit everyone

82.69.text:
across our society. Particularly important
to me are the changes WE want to make in the

88.22.text:
education system, allowing girls to have the
confidence and support of their male counterparts.

95.10.text:
This goes hand in hand with our plan to challenge
the way the media perceives and objectifies women.

101.05.text: I look forward to the Women's Equality Party

104.87.text:
working along side the main political parties.
In fact, in my ideal world, all MPs would

111.09.text:
be members of our party and Parliament would
have to take gender issues seriously.

116.64.text:
While we wait for that to happen, WE can, together,
ensure that women's voices are heard and women's

123.06.text:
rights are acknowledged across our society.
Behind all of this is the brilliant work of

128.73.text:
party leader, Sophie Walker, who I have the
great honour of introducing today.

151.19.text:
Good morning everyone, and welcome.
What a wonderful morning.

156.28.text:
This morning, we take a big step towards doing
politics differently.

164.21.text:
To doing politics fairly.
To creating the kind of politics where women

171.51.text:
and men are heard equally, and Britain does
better as a result.

177.63.text:
I’m Sophie Walker and I’m the leader of
the Women’s Equality Party.

183.28.text:
[Applause and cheering]
Thank you, thank you, thank you.

202.47.text:
Beside me sit some of our members who have
worked directly on the policies that we’re

208.11.text:
about to announce.
I’m delighted to welcome them today along

212.29.text:
with the many, many others here too who have helped
us to get to this point. We are truly grateful,

217.98.text:
and we are inspired by your approach that has been
both creative and pragmatic.

224.96.text:
As I look around this room and consider how
far we've travelled, it seems incredible

230.88.text:
that this wonderful party was set up just
six months ago by Sandi Toksvig and Catherine Mayer.

251.31.text:
Together they came up with the idea of building
a new collaborative force in British politics.

257.88.text:
A collaboration of people of all genders,
ages, backgrounds, ethnicities, beliefs and

267.19.text:
experiences who share the determination to
see women enjoy the same rights and opportunities

274.60.text:
as men so that all can flourish.
On behalf of the many thousands who, like

280.05.text:
me, jumped at the chance to be part of this,
I would like to thank Catherine and Sandi,

284.84.text:
whose courage and vision kick-started our
extraordinary journey.

308.22.text: Right! It’s 2015. It’s nearly a hundred

312.90.text: years since women won the right to vote and yet:

318.74.text: Men outnumber women in Parliament by two to one.

322.53.text:
Women’s experiences of work, healthcare,
crime and education are not heard and our

328.90.text:
legislation is often lacking and ineffective.
Two women are killed by a partner or former

337.13.text:
partner every week and for many others the
fear of being attacked is something they live

342.00.text:
with daily.
Our society is not at ease with itself.

348.25.text:
Women are represented in adverts and the media
as sex objects and victims, rather than individuals

354.42.text:
with ambitions and ideas.
Our children are held back by the limits imposed

360.43.text:
on them by gender stereotypes.
And our economy is out of balance:

365.19.text:
It is time to wake up to the real gender pay
gap that sits behind so many of the problems

371.14.text:
women face.
Overall, last year, men earned £516bn, and

380.36.text:
women earned £271bn.
That is a difference of £245bn.

389.16.text:
Why?
Because millions of women are being paid less

393.65.text:
than their male colleagues.
They are leaving work because they can’t

398.08.text:
afford childcare.
They are not returning to work when their

401.37.text:
children are older because they’re now caring
for elderly parents.

404.37.text:
They are working in part-time and unstable
jobs because they are the only ones that afford

410.12.text:
them flexibility.
This all adds up not just to a gap in earnings

415.64.text:
but a gap in power.
When British men earn £245bn more than British

426.01.text:
women every year - it is no surprise that
women have so little say in our society.

432.79.text:
WE are here to change that.
[Applause]

451.86.text:
A great many pressure groups and campaigners
and individuals have made great progress in

457.22.text:
fighting for the rights of women in all areas
of life.

461.02.text:
Without the inspirational work of the Suffragettes,
we would have no women in Parliament at all.

466.44.text:
Without the dedication of the Women’s Liberation
Movement in the 1960s and the 1970s we couldn’t

471.61.text:
hold employers to account over the pay gap
because the Equal Pay Act of 1970 wouldn’t exist.

477.13.text: But instead of celebrating these achievements

480.26.text:
and continuing to move forward, instead of
adopting the recommendations made by today’s

485.54.text:
brilliant women’s organisations - of which
there are many - British institutions choose

491.61.text:
instead now to look the other way.
Our history books neglect female activism

497.67.text:
and our media lampoons female activists as
radical and irrational women whose contributions

503.77.text:
to political discourse do not deserve to be
taken seriously.

515.80.text: Recently, the Prime Minister expressed concern

518.84.text:
that his two daughters would be disadvantaged
because of their gender. He said “you can’t

524.65.text:
have true opportunity without real equality.”
Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of the opposition,

531.33.text:
has said “we will never be a successful
society in which all are able to achieve their

536.35.text:
potential until we have equality for women.”
These are great comments, right?

542.42.text:
They’re just comments.
They have been talking about delivering equality

547.82.text:
for far too long.
It seems to me that they are more interested

551.64.text:
in claiming the right to deliver equality
than actually delivering it.

564.60.text: Their only action is to shoot down any other

567.85.text:
party’s talk about how they might deliver
equality - reducing our right to participate

572.52.text:
to a cynical messaging contest.
Equality is not a manifesto detail to bickered over.

578.40.text:
It’s not politicians’ property,
to be doled out as they see fit.

582.79.text:
And WE are not a special interest party.
We are half the population!

600.22.text: Equality belongs to us. The political system

603.08.text:
belongs to us. We are within our rights to
lay claim to both and that is what WE are

609.42.text:
going to do.
WE are proposing to finally achieve equality

613.67.text:
for women - and thereby, for everyone - by
being a political party that works with all

619.15.text:
the other parties. so we can all move forward
together.

623.87.text:
It’s really a shame that this approach is
so unique in politics. It really shouldn’t be.

629.84.text:
Now don’t get me wrong, WE will not shy away
from the big debates. We will campaign hard for

637.01.text:
votes. We plan to stand our first candidates
next spring.

641.62.text:
But our approach means that WE don't have
to wait until the next election for change.

646.30.text:
I'm so tired of waiting for change.
WE will collaborate, WE will work with all

651.64.text:
those who share our goals, and together we
will build a movement for change.

657.22.text:
We have six clear objectives to bring about
an equal society for the good of everyone.

663.36.text:
Today we announce the first of the policies
to deliver those objectives.

667.58.text:
These are policies that our members and supporters
have been crafting for months, up and down

672.29.text:
the country, in homes and offices, in cafés
and community halls, in the hope of breaking

678.62.text:
the current political logjam.
David Cameron, Jeremy Corbyn, political leaders

683.95.text:
and activists from every party - if you really
want women to fulfil their potential, then

689.57.text:
take on these policies.
WE will stand against you at election time.

695.44.text:
But WE challenge you: put us out of business
first. Implement our policies first, and do it fast.

723.20.text: You have got some brilliant people about to speak.

725.90.text:
I will just say a little more shortly
and then I will hand over to them.

728.80.text:
I have to say that I am overwhelmed, after
these months and months of work, to be holding

736.21.text:
this document today.
The proposals here are designed to support

741.20.text:
women right through their lives.
So let’s start by looking at life for young girls.

747.84.text: My younger daughter is six years old.

751.64.text:
She loves science.
I hope she continues to love it.

755.74.text:
I hope she takes Physics at ‘A’ level.
We heard from a member of our party who took

760.66.text:
Physics at ‘A’ level.
She was one of two girls in a class of thirty.

766.44.text:
And she wrote to us that in one lesson her
teacher thought it would be funny if he “mathematically”

770.90.text:
proved on the board that women are the root
of all evil.

777.10.text:
Who thinks that’s funny?
WE don’t want any girl to feel that she’s

778.98.text:
a joke to her classmates and a joke to her teacher.
We want to expand children’s options.

786.61.text:
We want them - and their teachers - to understand
that it is normal to treat all people as equal.

793.25.text:
And WE say that schools should be judged on
the way they teach gender equality - and on

809.96.text:
School is of course not just the place where
children learn to read and write.

813.32.text:
It’s also where they start to form ideas
about how relationships work, and it’s where

818.34.text:
they put that into practice.
Already the boys in my little girl’s class

823.62.text:
think she’s second-class.
I don’t. I think she’s first class - even

830.18.text:
though she did wake me up three times last
night to check it was today I was doing my big speech.

840.69.text:
But I can’t bear the thought that sexist,
oppressive attitudes are going to accompany

844.62.text:
her right through school. Like many of
you, I’m starting to realise WE can

850.22.text:
do something about it.
We can support our children and young people

855.04.text:
by challenging the idea that some subjects and
clothes and toys are for girls, and others

860.52.text:
are for boys; we can provide independent careers
advice. We can recognise that aspiration has

867.87.text:
no gender; we can provide honest sex and relationships
education, so that our children’s first

874.77.text:
romantic forays are, as they should be -
respectful, consensual, joyful,

881.89.text: and only embarrassing in the right way.

887.36.text:
This way we believe that young women and men
will be better equipped to go out together

891.15.text:
into the world.
In the world of adults, WE expect women and

895.23.text:
men to enjoy equal pay and equal opportunity.
We want to tackle the imbalances that hold

900.49.text:
women back in the workplace and leave many,
such as those who are unpaid caregivers or

905.62.text:
in low paid jobs, especially vulnerable.
WE also want to support women in the workforce

910.83.text:
as they move into their 50s and 60s, tackling
the discrimination that older women face,

915.94.text:
and enabling them to maintain a successful
and enjoyable career and enjoy security in

920.82.text:
their retirement.
Of course, creating a fairer workplace isn’t

924.60.text:
just about equal pay.
It’s about supporting everyone, regardless

928.39.text:
of gender or sexual orientation to share the
joys and responsibilities of parenting and

934.55.text:
caregiving. It’s about freeing families
from the exorbitant cost of childcare.

940.65.text:
One of our members wrote to us:
“It is my decision to be stay at home mum,"

945.40.text:
she said. "I never thought I’d be a mum
and enjoy it immensely. [But] it saddens me

951.04.text:
that I have been out of the work force for
such a long time that getting a job that doesn’t

955.52.text:
just pay for childcare is nigh on impossible.
“I want my daughter, and daughters everywhere

961.64.text:
to realise their potential.”
This woman is one of at least 600,000 women

968.37.text:
in Britain who would prefer to work, if they
could afford to do so.

974.28.text:
WE want women to realise their potential,
and WE want to do it by providing a system

979.03.text:
of childcare that doesn’t cost the earth
- and doesn’t have to be waited for.

984.47.text:
WE believe that government-funded childcare
should be available for all children from

989.98.text:
the end of paid parental leave, and WE believe
this is a key area for government investment.

1008.60.text: WE would fully fund this by introducing a

1012.50.text:
single rate of tax relief on pension savings,
which would free up around six and a half billion pounds.

1018.70.text: This will support women as they build their careers and start families,

1023.00.text:
but it also protects
women who are low earners and part-time workers

1027.25.text:
to save for their pensions.
By enabling women to earn more, we can enable

1032.12.text:
them to save more. And only by doing both
can we solve the problem of women’s poverty

1037.67.text:
pensions and ensure dignity in retirement
for all.

1041.77.text:
I’ve talked a lot about mothers here.
It’s important to look also at the way we

1046.24.text:
treat fathers and fathers-to-be.
Just as women’s careers suffer when it’s

1050.75.text:
assumed they will take parental leave, men’s
family lives suffer when it’s assumed that they won’t.

1056.23.text: WE want more fathers to take more parental

1059.11.text:
leave and we’re going to make it more affordable
for them to do so. WE will also provide greater

1064.93.text:
support to same-sex parents, adoptive parents
and single parents.

1069.50.text:
And we will encourage more fathers to take
time away from work by changing attitudes

1074.02.text:
around who can and who should care.
Our aim is to make women free and equal.

1083.89.text:
But no woman can be free and equal
unless she is safe.

1088.38.text:
It is a stain on our society that women are
murdered, violated, assaulted and oppressed

1094.37.text:
because of their gender.
By diminishing women’s freedom to participate

1098.63.text:
in society, violence against women and girls
remains one of the highest barriers to gender equality.

1106.32.text: Sometimes, feeling free from sexual violence

1109.14.text:
means just being able to walk down the street
in peace.

1113.49.text:
Another of our members told us: “I want
to know what it feels like to come home at

1118.22.text:
night without fearing being attacked. I don’t
want to be catcalled in the street. I don't

1123.81.text:
want to be belittled and told to “smile,
darling.”

1127.94.text:
Our country has a gendered culture where men
are seen as entitled to dominate and the media

1132.32.text:
portrays women as sex objects.
The acts of everyday sexism that pervade our

1136.49.text:
culture must not be trivialized.
They must be challenged and they must be defeated.

1144.05.text:
Violence against women and girls, of course,
goes much deeper than everyday sexism.

1148.82.text:
The Women’s Equality Party believes in the
absolute right to a place of sanctuary for

1153.31.text:
women, children, and other survivors of sexual
and domestic violence.

1157.67.text:
And WE recognise the importance of specialist
services for women from black, Asian and minority

1163.25.text:
ethnic communities, for women with disabilities
and for women with insecure immigration status.

1169.35.text:
It is essential to fund support services to
help women rebuild their lives.

1174.56.text:
And WE must address the shamefully low prosecution
rates for domestic and sexual violence.

1192.64.text: WE must also tackle the awful abuse and exploitation that occurs in the sex trade.

1201.44.text: The Women’s Equality Party joins those who believe

1204.08.text:
that women should never be criminalised
for selling sex.

1208.92.text:
It is time to begin a process in the United
Kingdom to end demand for prostitution.

1224.00.text: First, we must invest in the support services

1227.34.text:
and opportunities that women need to exit
the sex industry.

1231.62.text:
And WE must drive a national conversation
about the reality of the sex industry as both

1236.58.text:
a cause and consequence of gender inequality.
And then, within two years, we should legislate

1243.82.text: to criminalise the purchase of sex.

1255.32.text:
Our policies support ordinary women and help
them to overcome the challenges of living

1260.02.text:
and working in a structurally sexist society.
The problems I have outlined this morning

1264.95.text:
would not be so profound if women were equal
decision-makers in the United Kingdom, if

1269.23.text:
they were proportionately represented in politics
and business and throughout working life.

1273.81.text:
We’ve made some progress, but the path to
shared power is taking too long to pave.

1279.10.text:
So WE have concluded that - as a temporary
measure - quotas are necessary.

1295.60.text: Women currently make up a third of Parliament.

1300.47.text:
So WE will put Parliament into “special
measures” for two elections.

1311.80.text: Political parties should field women in two-thirds

1314.51.text:
of seats - including two-thirds of safe seats.
We can have a 50/50 Parliament in a decade.

1326.88.text: In business, similarly, WE expect balance.

1329.61.text:
WE want to see a balanced board and a balanced
executive committee at all listed companies

1346.12.text:
This will not, as the scare-mongers suggest,
permit mediocrity.

1354.24.text: Rather it will stamp it out.

1366.36.text: It will eradicating the centuries-old system

1369.31.text:
of unwritten quotas, which have created institutions
in which a wealthy, white, male elite wields

1376.57.text:
far more power than the rest of us.
Britain’s refusal to accept difference creates mediocrity.

1383.52.text: We have thirty million women in the country;

1386.35.text:
I'm sure we can find 325 brilliant ones to
become MPs.

1404.36.text: And I'm sure we can find many, many more to

1407.53.text:
lead and inspire in our workplaces.
I am going to break off here to introduce

1412.26.text:
some of the people who have created our policies,
to tell you a bit more about them.

1415.74.text:
So, please welcome Catherine Riley, who is
going to be talking about equality in the media.

1425.20.text:
Thanks, Sophie. My name is Catherine Riley.
Six months ago, I heard about the Women's

1433.33.text:
Equality Party and I put my hand up to help.
I didn't expect to be handed the task of co-ordinating

1442.19.text:
but that serves me right for underestimating
how consultative and co-operative the party's

1447.35.text:
methods of drawing up its aims and how to
achieve them would be.

1453.10.text:
On the CV I sent to Sophie was listed my work
in magazine journalism over many years and

1458.62.text:
my academic research into women's representation,
writing and publication.

1464.63.text:
For a long time, I have been reading and reading
about journalism that sidelines women, that

1471.19.text:
sexualises women and that is reliant on a
male-centric news agenda from which women

1476.89.text:
are largely excluded. WE aim to change that.
I have also watched TV content that doesn't

1483.74.text:
represent me or the women I know. Where are
the women whose families aren't nuclear? The

1490.08.text:
black female bosses who aren't tokens? The
disabled women not participating in the Paralymics?

1497.78.text:
And the successful single women who don't
have a drink problem?!

1513.18.text:
Thank you. [Laughter]
Such content also just as importantly stereotypes

1518.51.text:
men in ways that limit all of us and WE aim
to change that.

1523.69.text:
I have looked for, but not found, equal coverage
of women playing sport. I have looked for,

1529.36.text:
but not found, fashion and beauty photography
that shows women with a healthy BMI. I have

1535.78.text:
looked for, but not found, safe spaces online
where hashtagging the word "feminism" doesn't

1541.65.text:
immediately invite vitriol and invective,
and WE aim to change that.

1547.37.text:
For starters, WE will say no to disrespect
and mobilise our supporters to challenge reporting

1553.89.text:
that undermines women, whether by trivialising
violence, reinforcing harmful stereotypes

1559.94.text:
or retouching photos in order to distort our
ideas about how real women should look.

1565.67.text:
Given the growing significance of social media,
WE also call for stronger and better enforced

1570.65.text: rules on trolling and online abuse.

1580.33.text:
Media co-operation is critical to achieving
equality so, think on. Because, while legislative

1587.18.text:
change is vitally important, cultural change
is also essential if we are to shift the way

1591.74.text:
gender works in this country. That's why I
put my hand up six months ago. I was tired

1597.23.text:
of talking and writing about these issues
and I wanted to act.

1601.36.text:
I believe these policies and the Women's Equality
Party itself will make real changes to our

1606.03.text:
media and to our country and our culture in
the months and years ahead. I can't wait for

1612.36.text:
that change.
I'll now hand over to Lily Borton, who will

1615.89.text:
introduce our policies on equal education
for all children.

1629.92.text: I'm Lily. I've recently finished a degree

1633.10.text:
in Maths with Spanish at Royal Holloway and
I join a list of female alumni as inspiring

1639.82.text:
as Suffragette Emily Davison, novelist George
Elliot and Elizabeth Blackwell, the first

1647.01.text:
female doctor in the UK and in the US. Royal
Holloway was founded as a college for women

1654.66.text:
in 1886 in recognition of the extraordinary
social benefits of women's education, but

1662.54.text:
130 years later, we still have work to do
to achieve true gender equality in education.

1671.48.text:
That's one of the reasons that when I heard
a party for women's equality was being started,

1677.26.text:
I knew I had to get involved. I went along
to the education policy evening, held in Bath

1683.59.text:
and it was a really amazing experience.
We began by talking about what education would

1690.51.text:
look like free from gender inequality. We
decided that individuals would be valued without

1697.73.text:
gender stereotyping and unconscious bias.
We decided that it would be normal to study

1703.68.text:
what you are interested in irrespective of
your gender. We decided that gender stereotypes

1710.00.text:
would be eradicated in toys, books and in
attitudes.

1714.76.text:
A group of younger people split off to talk
about the issues we face in education today

1721.25.text:
and we kept coming back to a lack of good
quality personal, social and health education.

1728.59.text:
A pressing need for serious education in relationships,
mental health, consent and entitlement.

1739.14.text:
We then went on to talk about how we would
tackle these issues and I am really proud

1744.67.text:
that many of our recommendations are included
in this document today, especially...

1757.72.text:
...especially in sex and relationships education,
which should be taken as seriously as any other subject.

1772.71.text:
And I know that Sex and Relationships Education
can alarm people, particularly for younger

1778.38.text:
children, but what we are talking about is
helping young people learn about themselves

1784.12.text:
and understand how to build and maintain healthy
relationships. Empowering young people through

1791.39.text:
education will ensure that they are in the
driving seat of their own lives and relationships

1797.50.text:
and that's what WE are striving to achieve.
I'm now going to hand over to Josemma Garrett

1807.90.text:
and Duncan Fisher, who are going to talk about
equal parenting.

1825.64.text: It has been my privilege to lead on the working group

1828.94.text:
for equal parenting and caregiving.
The working group, consisting of men and women,

1834.81.text:
were tasked with the job of thinking about
the existing barriers to equality at home

1840.83.text:
and identifying achievable solutions.
I am a mother, who talks about fathers for

1847.52.text: a living - it's a strange job.

1851.08.text:
For fifteen years, I've campaigned for equality
in parenting and there has been some slight

1857.34.text:
movement, but nothing like this.
This - this - is amazing.

1864.76.text:
I've been a campaigner for equality for eighteen
years, since the day that my first daughter

1871.56.text:
was born and I created the Fatherhood Institute.
From the earliest stage, we knew that equality

1879.74.text:
for women depended on men becoming closer
to their children.

1886.26.text:
I served on the board of the Equal Opportunities
Commission, where my job was to focus on the

1892.87.text:
question of who cares for children. But since
2008, the debate has gone dead.

1901.91.text:
Both Jes and I and a handful of others have
been writing and advocating the whole way

1908.99.text:
through, but nobody has been reading or listening.
And suddenly, WE arrives - and puts caring

1918.93.text:
fairly and squarely on the table, just like
they did in other European countries a generation ago.

1927.28.text:
And here I am - a father of two daughters -
actually part of this launch. This moment

1938.09.text:
is one of the most significant in my 18 years
of this work and I still can't believe it.

1965.24.text: WE propose a new way of talking and thinking

1968.55.text:
about parenting and caring. Equal paid leave
for both parents, including same sex parents,

1976.54.text:
allows choice within the family. It starts
the wider culture change of caring and will

1982.53.text:
change things significantly in the workplace.
Paying men 90% of their wages for six weeks

1990.11.text:
gives a definite message - their role in caring
for their own children is taken seriously and valued.

2008.76.text:
Imagine the difference in the workplace when
men and women are viewed as equally likely

2015.11.text: to take time off when they become parents.

2025.00.text:
Imagine the future expectations of boys and
girls who have seen mums and dads share caring

2032.17.text:
responsibility equally. Imagine how this simple
shift in the leave system can encourage a

2040.05.text:
wider attitudinal shift.
It says clearly that all parents matter -

2045.25.text:
to their children, to the workplace and to society.
Men are hard-wired to care for their children

2054.63.text:
just as women are, yet we rarely see this
reflected in policy.

2064.48.text: No more images of men as incompetent carers,

2069.31.text:
uninterested or lacking specific skills which
women are "born with".

2076.60.text: It is a total myth, one that puts unfair pressure on mothers

2081.24.text:
as well as underestimates fathers.
WE will reform services, both public and private,

2088.23.text:
to make it clear that a parent's gender or
sexual orientation does not determine their

2094.48.text: ability to care for their child.

2107.48.text:
WE talks about parenting as a joy and it talks
about the need to share it equally. Wow!

2117.56.text:
No other gender equality advocate or political
party is saying anything like that.

2125.15.text:
By focussing only equality in work and in
public life, we have devalued caring.

2133.60.text:
WE has turned all that on its head. Now, caring has
equal status with work and we are thinking

2141.57.text:
about equality in caring. This is little short
of a revolution in equality thinking in the UK.

2162.98.text:
These policies reflect the needs, expectations
and aspirations of men and women to care for

2167.94.text:
their children. We can have it all, but only
when we're in it together. And now, for the

2174.10.text:
first time, it feels like we genuinely can
be.

2178.25.text:
I would now like to introduce Alex Mitsy,
who will talk about equal pay.

2193.48.text: My name is Alex Mitsy and I am an employment

2196.23.text:
lawyer specialising in equality and discrimination,
and I am tremendously proud to have been involved

2203.10.text:
in developing the policies that you'll hear
about today.

2207.88.text:
As a lawyer, I like legal solutions. I like
it when we make effective laws and people

2214.66.text:
abide by them. But in this case, the laws
we have aren't working. The Equal Pay Act

2222.29.text:
has been on the statute books for forty five
years, the Sex Discrimination Act for nearly

2228.89.text:
forty, but women still earn far less than
men and the pace of change is slowing.

2235.04.text:
The gender pay gap is 19%. To put that into
context for you, from now - today - until

2243.20.text:
the new year, women are working for free.
I, for one, can think of better things to

2260.65.text:
The reasons for this are clear and well known:
women who have children or other caring responsibilities

2267.19.text:
suffer a massive financial penalty, which
persists throughout their working lives. Women

2273.53.text:
are overrepresented in lower paid jobs and
sectors and underrepresented in highly paid

2279.56.text:
jobs. These are often lazily dismissed as
women's lifestyle choices as if women choose

2286.56.text:
to be poor. But women don't make choices in
a vacuum. Our choices are constrained by social

2294.13.text:
and financial barriers and that's something
WE can change with political will and with

2299.75.text:
the policies WE are launching today.
We've consulted with businesses and civil

2305.53.text:
society, we've had the input of many many
people across the country and WE have concluded

2311.95.text:
that change is not just possible, but essential.
Our policies will bring pay disparities into

2321.47.text:
the open and force them to be addressed. We'll
require employers to be more flexible and

2328.28.text:
WE will spread caring responsibilities more
equally so that women have genuine choices

2334.16.text:
about their lives.
WE recognise that we need to take businesses

2339.00.text:
with us and work with them, not just lecture
from the sidelines and we're keenly aware

2345.09.text:
that women are more likely to do low-paid
work, more likely to suffer because of Government

2350.65.text:
cuts and more likely to retire in poverty
and so our policies are pragmatic and focussed

2358.53.text:
on achieving our goals and improving women's
lives.

2363.46.text:
In my work, I often see how women's potential
is wasted - how they hit brick walls because

2369.52.text:
their work is under-valued, because now, in
2015, they still have to choose between their

2375.53.text:
job and their family. But I also see how businesses
and individuals thrive when women are able

2382.25.text:
to participate and progress.
The conclusion is inescapable: neither our

2387.84.text:
economy nor our society can afford to under-value
women's work.

2393.34.text:
And I would now like to introduce Nimko Ali,
who will be talking about violence against women.
Thank you.

2411.16.text: My name is Nimko Ali and I'm an activist and

2414.01.text:
a co-founder of Daughters of Eve, a not-for-profit
organisation that works with girls at risk

2418.80.text:
of female genital mutilation. As some of you
might know, I was subjected to FGM at the

2424.17.text:
age of 7 but it was not until 2003 that the
loopholes that allowed this act of violence

2430.31.text:
to be committed against British girls and
women like me overseas was closed. If we had

2436.24.text:
equal numbers of women in positions of
decision-making power and survivors' voices were heard,

2441.44.text: it would be less likely for these loopholes to exist.

2445.59.text:
My reasons for joining WE were intensely personal and
intensely political because these things go together.

2461.88.text:
Two of my sisters will this week lose their
lives at the hands of a current or ex-partner.

2467.92.text:
There is a young girl or a young woman out
there wondering whether the dress she wore

2473.13.text:
last night or how much she had to drink was
the reason she got raped.

2477.45.text:
If nothing changes, my four year old niece
will grow up with the same daily deluge of

2482.52.text:
media that represents her as a second class
citizen and her peers in Britain and around

2488.11.text:
the world will be subjected to assault, exploitation,
trafficking and many other forms of violence daily.

2496.72.text: Too often, politicians pretend that violence

2500.67.text:
against women and girls is something that
has always happened and always will.

2505.08.text:
WE don't believe that. With better education about
consent, respect and a strong stance against

2511.78.text:
the trivialisation of violence in the media
and through strengthening the criminal justice system,

2531.35.text:
In the meantime, WE will provide survivors
of all forms of violence with the support

2536.52.text:
they need by increasing funding for shelters,
rape crisis centres, legal aid and family

2543.34.text:
counselling. WE recognise that survivors have
diverse needs and experiences, that women

2553.47.text:
from black, Asian and ethnic minority communities
have distinct needs as do women with disabilities

2560.30.text:
and insecure immigration status and so do
women living in poverty or those suffering

2565.98.text:
from addiction.
OK... sorry, I've just lost my notes.
There you go. Here it is.

2578.96.text: I wish I could say that I woke up one day

2581.27.text:
and thought I really wanted to change the
world and become a campaigner, but ultimately,

2585.43.text:
I came face to face too often with the results
of my silence about FGM and how that was complacent.

2593.21.text:
Some of my experience in political lobbying
and working with those who don't understand

2598.96.text:
the needs of survivors have been as painful
as the dismissal of my experience as a child.

2605.08.text:
Speaking out is not just about changing our
political landscape, it's about letting the

2609.52.text:
individuals claim ownership of their lives.
And through thousands of individual voices,

2631.28.text:
It is now my great pleasure to introduce Honor
Barber, who will be talking about equal representation.

2644.40.text:
Hello, I'm Honor. I'm 17 and I co-founded the
Hampstead and Kilburn branch of the
Women's Equality Party.

2658.08.text: I got involved, like thousands of others because

2660.89.text:
we've had enough. We're meant to be happy
with just 29% of MPs being women. We're meant

2668.00.text:
to be happy with just 25% of FTSE 100 boards
involving women. We're meant to be happy with

2674.80.text:
more women reporting sexual violence though
the numbers of assaults are rising dramatically.

2680.71.text:
We're meant to be happy with the idea that
we can do anything, but still we're taught

2684.40.text:
that our appearance matters the most. We're
meant to be happy with the Equal Pay Act though

2689.78.text:
women are still guaranteed to get paid 19%
less than men. We're 51% of the population
and we're not happy.

2711.73.text:
We can't keep waiting for a little percentage
increase. We need proper representation and

2716.93.text:
we need it now.
The policies we are launching today will take

2721.41.text:
a bold new approach to finally achieving equal
representation through policies in politics

2727.20.text:
and business, including the "Help to Fly" initiative,
we are supporting women entrepreneurs to start

2732.72.text:
their own businesses and young women getting
into politics.

2736.82.text:
As a party, WE have decided to achieve our
goals, we need quotas. Quotas might be scary,

2743.11.text:
but still not achieving equality when I'm
80 and most of you are dead is much, much scarier.

2762.38.text:
As Sophie said, quotas are a short-term measure
to ensure that in 10 years' time, this conversation

2767.80.text:
will be over because we will have a 50/50
Parliament and equal representation of women

2773.04.text:
on boards. And we will be able to stop being
happy with 20% representation but our rightful 50.

2780.76.text:
This changes the world for women of my
generation. Instead of apologetically getting

2785.34.text:
on with jobs while men are promoted above
them, young women will be able to see the

2789.91.text:
possibility of becoming board members
regardless of their gender.

2802.16.text: It is true that someone who isn't a woman

2804.79.text:
can represent women. However, in a country
where we are still taxed for having periods

2810.54.text:
and women in politics are told to "calm down"
you have to question whether women are being represented properly.

2827.56.text:
The answer: they aren't. Having equal representation
in Parliament will not only encourage young

2833.25.text:
women into politics, but will ensure that
representation - the most fundamental part

2837.90.text:
of democracy - is properly carried out. WE
can ensure, by women gaining equal representation,

2844.07.text:
that women of my generation won't have to
worry that if they get to the top their dresses

2849.36.text:
and nails will be more important than their
brains and ideas.

2859.72.text: For the young girls who come after us, for our own

2862.77.text:
daughters, will never have a shortage of strong,
successful women to look up to.

2873.00.text: This means there will come a time when the

2875.34.text:
idea of gender inequality will be just as
ridiculous as women's complete lack of representation

2881.66.text:
from all areas of public life.
This isn't an easy fight: the Women's Equality

2887.39.text: Party is distracting me from my studies!

2891.80.text:
To be here, I have had to get permission to
skip an English lesson and I've also spoken

2896.66.text:
at events past 9 o'clock on a school night.
The Women's Inequalty.... The Women's Equality

2903.52.text:
Party may be inconvenient, but the idea that
in ten years we could have a country where

2909.18.text:
gender equality exists is worth the inconvenience.
Today, we've come a step closer to ensuring

2915.94.text:
our children will never have to skip school
for gender equality. Thank you.

2950.54.text: If you, like me, are tired of waiting for equality…

2955.26.text:
Stop waiting.
Join us, join in.

2961.42.text:
WE are already making a difference.
And the bigger WE are the more difference

2967.96.text:
WE will make.
Thank you very much.
